item.title: cahill wins pitchers' duel as athletics edge blue jays
item.description: trevor cahill came out on top in a pitching duel with ricky romero, tossing eight brilliant innings to pick up his first win of the season as the oakland athletics edged the toronto blue jays 2-1 on thursday.

item.title: former mets, blue jays 1b carlos delgado retires
item.description: carlos delgado officially gave up wednesday on coming back from a hip injury, announcing his retirement from baseball two years after he was sidelined with 473 career home runs.

item.title: is it time for the bulls to spend serious money?
item.description: the bulls have yet to surpass the luxury tax threshold, but will a contending team make ownership willing to splurge on talent?

item.title: darfur referendum set for july 1: state media
item.description: sudan will hold a referendum on making darfur a single region in july, state media said on sunday, pushing ahead with a vote which would derail any peace talks to resolve a conflict that washington calls genocide.

item.title: at war: bin laden's killing helps president's poll numbers
item.description: the killing of osama bin laden has given president obama a sharp bump in his job performance approval rating among both republican and democratic voters, according to the latest new york times/cbs news poll.

item.title: china says middle east should solve problems itself
item.description: middle east countries should be left to themselves to resolve the problems they currently face without outside interference, a chinese vice foreign minister said during a visit to the region.

item.title: dollar general misses estimates
item.description: dollar general corp missed wall street profit expectations after taking markdowns to clear slow-selling apparel out of its stores, sending shares down about 5 percent.

item.title: man jailed after alleged sex threat to on-air radio host
item.description: an orlando judge on tuesday denied bail to a man accused of threatening to sexually assault a christian radio host while she was at work during a live broadcast.

item.description: in his first visit to harlem as president, barack obama attended a $30,800-a-person fund-raiser.

item.description: hostility from the senate is making confirmation unlikely for dr. donald m. berwick, the temporary administrator of medicare and medicaid.

item.description: residents of southern michigan were cleaning up on monday after a violent storm ripped through the region, leaving at least 30,000 people without power, authorities said.

item.description: president barack obama has decided not to release photos of al qaeda leader osama bin laden dead, the white house said on wednesday.

item.title: journeyman torres finds welcome home in vancouver
item.description: until raffi torres scored to give the vancouver canucks a 1-0 win over the boston bruins in game one of the stanley cup finals on wednesday, he had missed as many games through suspension as he had playoff goals.

item.title: marking d-day with massive paintball battle
item.description: mighty forces are gathering in the northeast corner of oklahoma, and they're itching for a fight. they're well-organized, high-spirited and heavily armed -- with paintball guns.

item.title: bofa to spin off $5 billion private equity unit
item.description: bank of america corp plans to spin off its last large private equity fund, with more than $5 billion in assets, and has no plans to make new private equity investments, a company spokesman said on tuesday.

item.description: customs officers have seized 1,932 karaoke machines bearing counterfeit logos, a u.s. customs and border protection spokesman said on thursday.

item.description: right from the start, derrick rose wondered why he couldn't be the mvp. it turns out, nothing could stop him.

item.description: scientists say they have discovered the first fossil of a dinosaur in angola, and that it's a new creature, heralding a research renaissance ...

item.title: "cooperative" mladic to face tribunal on friday
item.description: former bosnian serb military commander ratko mladic used his power to commit atrocities that tore a nation apart and destroyed communities, and he must be held to account, a u.n. war crimes prosecutor said on wednesday.

item.title: tennessee senate vote due on teacher union bargaining ban
item.description: the republican majority tennessee senate is expected to approve on monday a proposal that bans unions from negotiating teacher contracts with school boards, the bill's sponsor said.

item.title: nigerian islamist sect rejects amnesty offer
item.description: a radical islamist sect in remote northeastern nigeria, blamed for almost daily killings and attacks, on monday rejected an offer of an amnesty.

item.title: costco to enter high-priced chicago gas market
item.description: costco wholesale corp will soon start selling gasoline at its chicago warehouse store, a move that should drive more sales even if it decreases the rate of profitability at the club.

item.title: new drugs often marketed ahead of crucial data
item.description: data that could save money and help doctors make smarter treatment decisions are often unavailable at the time new medicines hit the market, according to u.s. researchers.

item.title: suspect in dodger stadium assault held in jail
item.description: an ex-convict held for nearly two weeks as a suspect in the severe beating of a san francisco giants fan at dodger stadium was ordered on friday to remain jailed without bond on an alleged parole violation.

item.title: an obama insider, running the race from afar
item.description: jim messina, previously a white house deputy chief of staff, is running the president's re-election campaign, which will formally open its doors in chicago this week.

item.title: floods sweep through eastern montana
item.description: flooding in montana caused the cancellation of several high school graduations and fishermen were trapped by washed out roads on saturday.

item.description: the rail's contributors and a special guest picker make their kentucky derby selections.

item.description: president bashar al-assad accepted the resignation of his cabinet on tuesday as thousands of government supporters took to the streets of the capital.

item.description: the number of bodies found in mass graves in northeastern mexico has risen to 183, officials said tuesday.

item.title: rajaratnam defense in last shot to urge acquittal
item.description: raj rajaratnam's lawyer took a last shot at trial of keeping his client out of prison, blasting the credibility of key witnesses and telling jurors the government failed to prove the hedge fund manager broke insider trading laws.

item.title: uk's william and kate off on honeymoon -- at last
item.description: britain's prince william and his new wife kate have set off for a delayed honeymoon following their april 29 wedding, st james's palace said on tuesday.

item.title: world's largest rolls-royce showroom opens
item.description: the largest rolls-royce showroom in the world has opened in -- where else? -- abu dhabi. you were expecting orlando?

item.description: the miami heat banished memories of their worst loss of the season by returning the favor to the san antonio spurs in a 110-80 thrashing of the nba leaders on monday.

item.description: singer mariah carey on saturday gave birth to twins, delivering a boy and a girl on the third anniversary of her wedding to nick cannon, her spokeswoman said.

item.title: penguins' crosby returns to practice
item.description: penguins center sidney crosby returned to the ice for the first time since missing 29 games with a concussion but did not know when he could play in a game.

item.title: new ivory coast army turns against ex-allies
item.description: government forces attacked fighters from a militia that had been allied with them in the fight against the former president, laurent gbagbo.

item.title: twitter ceo says 80 percent of advertisers renew
item.description: more than 80 percent of the companies that advertise on twitter renew their marketing efforts on the microblogging service, the company's chief executive said on wednesday.

item.title: eu draft u.n. resolution on syria could hurt stability: china
item.description: china warned on tuesday that a european draft resolution asking the u.n. security council to condemn syria would not defuse tension in the region, suggesting beijing could block it if it is submitted for a vote.

item.title: japan urges calm over food export fears
item.description: japan called on the world not to impose "unjustifiable" import curbs on its goods as french president nicolas sarkozy was due to arrive on thursday, the first leader to visit since an earthquake and tsunami damaged a nuclear plant, sparking the worst nuclear crisis since chernobyl in 1986.

item.title: japan crisis drags, france wants global nuclear reform
item.description: japan's nuclear crisis stretched to three weeks on friday with radiation widening from a crippled power plant and scant hope of a quick resolution.

item.description: the dropcam is a small webcam that captures live video and distributes it to a remote computer or handheld device.

item.title: japan scrambles to save nuclear plant
item.description: japan's nuclear crisis appeared to be spinning out of control on wednesday after workers withdrew briefly from a stricken power plant because of surging radiation levels and a helicopter failed to drop water on the most troubled reactor.

item.title: appliance makers to shoppers: prices will rise
item.description: whirlpool and electrolux said shoppers will have to shell out more money to buy washers and dryers this year as the companies pay more for steel, copper and oil.

item.title: arizona's williams saves his a-game for, well, games
item.description: only kemba walker and jimmer fredette have captivated the crowds and moved the prospective n.b.a. needle more than arizona's derrick williams.

item.title: china 2010 census shows 1.3 billion population
item.description: china's population grew to 1.34 billion by 2010, according to census figures released on thursday, up 5.9 percent from the 1.27 billion counted in the last census in 2000, and lower than the 1.4 billion population some demographers had projected for the latest tally.

item.description: the u.s. economy appears to be running dangerously close to stall speed, and the rest of the world may not have enough oomph to compensate.

item.title: bank policy heavyweights fight it out
item.description: two prominent europeans ? mervyn king and jacques de larosiere ? are offering contrasting views about bank stability that could sway the debate over banking standards, an economist writes.

item.title: french first lady fuels pregnancy rumors
item.description: french first lady carla bruni has fanned rumors she is pregnant, clutching a shawl to her belly during a newspaper interview and fending off inquiries with the words "my lips are sealed to protect something..."

item.title: regulators to vote on mortgage securities rules: report
item.description: banks will be forced to keep some risk when they securitize all but the most conservatively written mortgages under rules that regulators are expected to vote on tuesday, the new york times reported on monday.

item.title: radiation injuries hinder work at japan's nuclear plant
item.description: radiation injuries to three workers complicated the battle to control japan's earthquake-damaged nuclear plant while fear of contamination from the world's worst nuclear crisis in 25 years grew both at home and abroad.

item.title: visa backs twitter co-founder's mobile venture
item.description: visa inc has thrown its weight behind a mobile payments venture created by twitter co-founder jack dorsey.

item.title: high radiation levels at japanese plant raise new worry
item.description: highly radioactive water has been found at a second reactor at a crippled nuclear power station in japan, the plant's operator said, as fears of contamination escalated two weeks after a huge earthquake and tsunami battered the complex.

item.title: iaea tracks radiation leaks at japan's crippled plant
item.description: japan's earthquake-hit nuclear complex is still emitting radiation but the source is unclear, a senior u.n. atomic agency official said, as workers faced another day of struggle on wednesday to cool damaged reactor cores.

item.title: some progress at japan reactors as disaster toll rises
item.description: japan hoped power lines restored to its stricken nuclear plant may help solve the world's worst atomic crisis in 25 years, triggered by an earthquake and tsunami that also left more than 21,000 people dead or missing.

item.title: radiation anxiety grows in disaster-struck japan
item.description: global anxiety rose over radiation from japan's crippled nuclear plant even as engineers won ground in their battle to avert disaster from the world's worst atomic crisis since chernobyl.

item.description: a special election to replace a republican about to be appointed to the united states senate should be open to all candidates, nevada's secretary of state ruled on monday.

item.title: japan finds plutonium at stricken nuclear plant
item.description: plutonium found in soil at the crippled fukushima nuclear complex heightened alarm on tuesday over japan's protracted battle to contain the world's worst atomic crisis in 25 years.

item.title: france and u.s. to help japan in nuclear crisis
item.description: france and the united states are to help japan in its battle to contain radiation from a crippled nuclear complex where plutonium finds have raised public alarm over the world's worst atomic crisis since chernobyl in 1986.

item.title: engineers toil to pump out japan plant
item.description: japanese engineers struggled on sunday to pump radioactive water from a crippled nuclear power station after radiation levels soared in seawater near the plant more than two weeks after it was battered by a huge earthquake and a tsunami.

item.title: disaster-hit japan faces protracted nuclear crisis
item.description: japan appeared resigned on monday to a long fight to contain the world's most dangerous atomic crisis in 25 years after high radiation levels complicated work at its crippled nuclear plant.

item.title: eu's juncker weighs "soft" greek debt restructuring
item.description: greek debt could undergo a "soft" restructuring if athens embarks on major reforms and accelerates privatization to raise funds, the chairman of euro zone finance ministers jean-claude juncker said on tuesday.

item.title: granderson improves
item.description: curtis granderson's recovery from a strained right internal oblique muscle is progressing rapidly, raising the possibility that he could play thursday at yankee stadium against the tigers.

item.title: the anti-james twitter crowd gathers
item.description: the anti-lebron james faction of cleveland cavaliers fans has found a new way to protest against their former star: by supporting the dallas mavericks in the nba finals.

item.description: a look at recent plays about war that have been produced on and off broadway.

item.title: mauritanian police use teargas to break up protest
item.description: security forces using teargas and batons dispersed several hundred anti-government protesters in the mauritanian capital nouakchott on monday, the most serious clash in the west african state for nearly two months.

item.title: yankees say rodriguez's cousin has not violated restrictions
item.description: members of the commissioner's office were said to have spoken with the yankees and were satisfied that yuri sucart, who was implicated by alex rodriguez as his steroid provider, was not in violation of restrictions that were imposed two years ago.

item.title: breast cancer may not change lifespan for older women
item.description: older women who are diagnosed with early-stage breast cancer can expect to live just as long as peers without breast cancer, according to a new study.

item.title: daybreak reveals huge devastation in tsunami-hit japan
item.description: japan confronted devastation along its northeastern coast on saturday, with fires raging and parts of some cities under water after a massive earthquake and tsunami that likely killed at least 1,000 people.

item.title: quake-hit japan nuclear plant faces fresh threat
item.description: japan battled to contain a radiation leak at an earthquake-crippled nuclear plant on sunday, but faced a fresh threat with the failure of the cooling system in a second reactor.

item.title: japan fights to avert nuclear meltdown after quake
item.description: japan battled on monday to prevent a nuclear catastrophe and to care for millions of people without power or water in its worst crisis since world war two, after a massive earthquake and tsunami that are feared to have killed more than 10,000 people.

item.title: as nato claims progress in libya, a u.s. deadline is put to the test
item.description: the obama administration appears to be ignoring a statute requiring hostilities to cease after two months if congress has not authorized them to continue.

item.title: new explosion shakes stricken japanese nuclear plant
item.description: a fresh explosion rocked a damaged japanese nuclear power plant on tuesday where engineers have been pumping sea water into a reactor to prevent a catastrophic meltdown in the wake of a devastating earthquake and tsunami.

item.title: the lede: march 17 updates on japan's nuclear crisis and earthquake aftermath
item.description: on thursday, the lede continues to supplement reporting from our colleagues in japan on the aftermath of last week's devastating earthquake, including efforts to regain control of a damaged nuclear plant.

item.title: fire at japan nuclear reactor heightens radiation threat
item.description: japan raced to avert a catastrophe after fire broke out on wednesday at a nuclear plant that has sent low levels of radiation wafting into tokyo, prompting some people to flee the capital and triggering growing international alarm at the escalating crisis.

item.description: reggie bush didn't seem to take the new orleans saints' drafting of rb mark ingram as a good sign.

item.title: divvying up the water down under
item.description: australian government agencies have far more information about the water supply and more say in how it is used -- and water markets flourish.

item.title: japan scrambles to avert nuclear disaster, global fears mount
item.description: operators of a quake-crippled nuclear plant in japan said they would try again on thursday to use military helicopters to douse overheating reactors, as u.s. officials warned of a rising risk of a catastrophic radiation leak from spent fuel rods.
